Leonardo da Vinci - Bringing the Renaissance genius back to life would be an incredible opportunity to learn from one of history's most innovative thinkers. Da Vinci was a true polymath, with expertise in art, science, engineering, and mathematics. He could share insights on how to approach complex problems from multiple angles, and his inventive mind could inspire new ideas and innovations.

Cleopatra - As the last pharaoh of ancient Egypt, Cleopatra was a powerful and intelligent leader who ruled during a time of great cultural and political change. She could offer valuable insights into the history of Egypt and the ancient world, as well as her experiences as a female leader in a male-dominated society.

Albert Einstein - As one of the most influential scientists of the 20th century, Einstein's ideas and theories continue to shape our understanding of the universe. He could share his thoughts on the latest advancements in physics and cosmology, as well as his perspectives on the intersection of science and philosophy.

Marie Curie - As the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and one of the most important scientists of the 20th century, Curie's work in radioactivity and nuclear physics revolutionized our understanding of the atomic world. She could discuss the challenges she faced as a woman in a male-dominated field and the importance of perseverance and determination in pursuing scientific breakthroughs.

Leonidas of Sparta - As the leader of the 300 Spartans who fought against the Persian army at the Battle of Thermopylae, Leonidas is a legendary figure in ancient Greek history. He could share his insights on leadership, strategy, and the importance of discipline and honor in battle. Additionally, he could provide a unique perspective on the cultural and political landscape of ancient Greece during a time of great turmoil and change.
